Dr. Oldham is an educator at SGMS and SGHS, where he teaches World History, American History, and Topics and Research in History. While he is a veteran of 22 years in the classroom, Dr. Oldham believes in a Growth Mindset—that we are all lifelong learners—and he learns something new every day from his students and fellow educators to add to his ever-expanding teacher toolbox.

Recently, SGHS junior and senior class representatives, class sponsors and administrators held an online Zoom meeting regarding the possibility of hosting prom this summer, as the event was originally postponed from the 2019-2020 school year.

As a group, it was decided that in order to prioritize the health and safety of the community and students, SGHS will not hold a prom for the 2019-2020 school year. While we are disappointed that our students could not experience this important tradition this year, this group of SGHS student representatives recognize the responsibility resting upon these decisions, and they made the decision they felt would best benefit our community.

Congratulations to wrestling coach Jared Bonnell and assistant wrestling coach Justin Roth, who were both honored with awards from the Missouri Wrestling Association!

Coach Bonnell was honored as the District 1 Girls Wrestling Coach of the Year, and Coach Roth was recognized as Assistant Coach of the Year!

Ste. Genevieve R-II Athletics Director Dr. Jeff Nix says that these two individuals could not be more deserving of the honors. As a team, the foundation of their coaching is rooted in their ability to build connections with their athletes.

“Coach Bonnell builds a great rapport with kids from all walks of life,” Dr. Nix says. “He has high expectations for his athletes, and he does a tremendous job in helping our athletes meet their goals. And Coach Roth consistently goes the extra mile, keeping up with students outside of wrestling about their academics and interests. He makes a lasting connection through the simple, genuine effort of getting to know the kids.”

Congratulations to Coach Bonnell and Coach Roth!

She loves to be outdoors and has a passion for making lifelong friends with the people in the community with special needs. Kassydey plans to attend Mineral Area College to pursue nursing. She wants to continue her education to become a pediatric nurse practitioner, specializing in Nephrology.

Students in Dr. Rhett Oldham's Topics and Research in History were used to eating foods from around the world each month when they received a package from Universal Yums, a company that sends out snacks and treats from a different country or region each month. Through the pandemic, students have missed out on treats from Brazil in March and Scandinavia in April in the classroom, so packages were delivered to students' homes, using social distances norms and guidelines!

The contents of the boxes change each month as the company highlights the best snacks from each featured country, but students can always expect a mix of flavors, and only authentic snacks from the featured country are included.

While the Yum Box items were fun and enthusiastically received by the students, Dr. Oldham said that the real gift was having the opportunity to check in on his students, say hello, and check on how everyone is doing in these unprecedented times!

#StillLearning #InThisTogether #SGFamily

- Bryce Trollinger with a trumpet solo

- Flute trio of Jamison Kemper, Hannah Reeves, Emma Stovall

- Annie Yang with an alto sax solo
- Jacob Kirchner with a mallet solo

Congratulations to all of these students on their performances!

SG R-II families, it has been determined that we will be unable to hold a full graduation ceremony for seniors and their parents on Saturday, May 16.

At this time, graduation will be held on Saturday, June 20, at 8 p.m., and prom will be held the night before, on June 19, at 7 p.m. (location to be determined). We do not yet have information available regarding cap and gown pick-up.

If, moving forward, circumstances do not allow us to hold these events in June, we would plan on using a set of alternative dates in July (Friday, July 24, for prom and Saturday, July 25, for graduation). Of course, these events will also need to be cleared and deemed safe by CDC guidelines and our local health department.

Students Enlisting in the Military: Seniors enlisting in the military will have the opportunity to participate in a “presentation of diplomas” ceremony at 2 p.m. on Saturday, May 16. Those families will be contacted with more information soon.

Congratulations to senior Jared Kenik, the Rotary Student of the Month for April from Ste. Genevieve High School! Jared is the son of Jill and David Kenik.

Jared's scholastic honors include: being ranked in the top 15% of his graduating senior class, earning A Honor Roll each semester, being selected for the English III and Advanced Chemistry awards and being an A+ student. Jared has also excelled in the band having been selected as outstanding soloist for guitar in multiple jazz festivals. He has also been an active member of a number of clubs and organizations including SGHS Scholar Bowl, Future Teachers of America, and German Club. Jared has been a member of the SGHS wrestling and track teams.

In his free time, Jared enjoys lifeguarding, playing his jazz guitar and playing video games. He plans to attend Mineral Area College and then transfer to Missouri Science & Technology and major in chemistry with a focus in Science Education.

Congratulations to Dr. Tracey Eatherton, Family and Consumer Sciences Educator at Ste. Genevieve High School, for being recognized with the 2020 Lifetime Achievement award from Missouri Educators of Family and Consumer Sciences and Human Services (MoEFACS)!

Dr. Eatherton is being recognized as a one who has demonstrated innovation in the classroom through use of technology and the improvement of dual credit for students in her school. Dr. Eatherton is credited with “leading the charge with area FACS instructors for several years to perfect the high school dual credit program designed to prepare students for the completion of the Nationally Recognized Child Development Associate Credential, ” states Jennifer Sikes, Early Childhood Department chair at Mineral Area College.

#SGExcellence #GoodNewsSGR2

http://www.sgdragons.org/article/234746?org=ste-genevieve-school-district

Congratulations to the SGMS Science Bowl team, who recently participated in the regional competition for the 30th National Science Bowl®, held at Washington University!

The National Science Bowl® is a nationwide academic competition that tests students' knowledge in all areas of science and mathematics. Teams face-off in a fast-paced question-and-answer format, being tested on a range of science disciplines including biology, chemistry, Earth and space science, physics, energy and math.

The team included Adam Allen, Charlie Corbett, Sophia Fritsch, Jeremiah Kunz and Aidan Lewis. This was the first year SGMS had a team, and 11 schools sent teams to participate in the event! The team’s coach and advisor SGMS science teacher Katie Deimund said that the team showed a great effort competing against some of the established teams—they even won one of their five rounds! The group learned from the experience, and knows what to expect come this time next year!

#SGExcellence

Both Ste. Genevieve Elementary and Bloomsdale Elementary robotics teams competed in the 2020 Mineral Area VEX IQ Challenge held on Saturday, Feb. 8, 2020.

Bloomsdale Elementary had three teams compete, and all improved their rankings by 10 to 15 places from their first competition earlier this year. The teams scored 6th, 15th and 17th in the qualification rounds. One team advanced to the finals, where they scored 92 points and earned 4th place!

Ste. Genevieve Elementary had three teams compete, and all of the teams performed well! Despite some technical difficulties, the teams continued to problem-solve and earned more and more points each round. The Robotic Dragons team placed in the top 10 teams during the qualification rounds and advanced to the finals, where they won 5th place!

Rotary Club of Ste. Genevieve
February 24 at 10:15 AM ·

Five local high school students had the opportunity to attend the 2020 Rotary Camp Enterprise seminar on Feb. 21 at the Career and Technology Center in Cape Girardeau. The SGHS students included Alison Braun, Cami Grass and Karissa Holst, and the Valle Catholic students included Mallory Kist and Emma Langeneckert.

The students who attended are members of the Ste. Genevieve Rotary Interact Club. The seminar offered students the opportunity to meet with area business leaders to learn how to establish and operate successful businesses. Participants were able to build upon valuable skills while interacting with one another and exploring the world of business through activities and enterprise simulations.

This seminar was sponsored by the following Rotary Clubs: Cape Girardeau, Cape Girardeau County, Cape Girardeau West, Jackson, Perryville, Ste. Genevieve and Sikeston.

Photo Caption: SGHS student Cami Grass, SGHS student Alison Braun, Valle Catholic student Emma Langeneckert, Valle Catholic student Mallory Kist and SGHS student Karissa Holst.

SGHS wrapped up its annual Snowcoming activities last week!

At Friday’s pep assembly, the Rolly Chair game returned with a familiar rivalry: social studies teacher Brian Craft versus math teacher Cody Schwent. In Rolly Chair, faculty members play basketball from rolling chairs, as students run them around the court. Craft’s team had been the reigning champion from last year, but on Friday, Schwent’s team stepped up and took the crown with a final score of 10- 5.

Teachers voted for the most spirited students for the 2020 Snowcoming King & Queen: Shaun Uzzell was chosen as king, and Sydney Eisenbeis was chosen as queen.

The festivities concluded with the 2020 Snowcoming PowderBuff volleyball game, played between the junior and senior boys’ teams, along with a team of faculty members. The senior Blue Team coached by Julia McKlin won the tournament against the junior and senior teams, and took on the faculty team to win 27-25!

Student Council members and sponsors were in charge of planning and preparing the activities for the week.

#GoBigGreen

Students in Coach Jessica Fallert’s Adaptive Physical Education class have been working on movement patterns, balance, coordination and the use of core muscles with their new adult tricycles!

The class raised the funds for their tricycles through Donors Choose, a nonprofit organization that allows individuals to donate directly to public school classroom projects. Coach Fallert says that she originally wanted to purchase one adult tricycle with safety equipment, but the generosity of those donating made it possible to order two with all of their accessories!

When they unpack the tricycles, the class also sets up small road signs and cones, so that they can work on spatial awareness and practice their sign recognition, a skill they work on in class, as well!

SGHS junior Ellie Naeger was named as the 2019 Patched Overalls Experience scholarship recipient!

Ellie will be attending Summer of Arts, a 4-week pre-college program at Otis College of Art and Design in Los Angeles, California. This program is offered to youth seeking to strengthen and enhance their art and design skills. Drawing Studio and Specialization courses are offered five days a week. Ellie will be working with practicing professionals to create original art, and she will earn three college credits upon completion of the program.

Ellie and her family met with Tyson Schaffner, Patched Overalls founder, along with Aaron Stacy, the student who was last year’s scholarship recipient, and his father, to talk about Aaron’s experience with the program.

The latest STEM project library aide Mrs. Sarah Carlson organized tasked students with building a boat that would from cardboard, straws, tape, stick glue, scissors and string. Each student in Mrs. Nicole Jenkin’s fourth grade class was given supplies in order to create a small “boat” that would be tested at the end of the class period to see if it would float. The goal was to create a design that would hold up to the test, no matter what type of “boat” the students decided to make.

When their time was up and after the students tested their creations, the class debriefed by discussing which boats worked best, which physical attributes seemed to be more conducive to floating and what other materials could be used for the same project that might improve results!

#STEMLearning

Students in Ms. Gettinger’s kindergarten class at Bloomsdale Elementary held their own Gratitude Parade, complete with personal notes of thanks and a route designed through coding!

After reading “Balloons Over Broadway” by Melissa Sweet and learning about the history of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, the students worked in pairs to decorate balloons with notes and artwork on the people and things for which they were thankful. That’s where the coding comes in! The students had the opportunity to use the library’s new Bee-Bots, a robot designed for young children to teach sequencing, estimation and problem solving! Students use directional keys on the top of the robot to enter up to 40 commands, including sending the Bee-Bot forward, backward, left and right. Ms. Gettinger’s students created a simple route and sent the balloons through a parade around the classroom!

#Thankful

The Community Counseling Center is looking to hire a Youth Day Treatment Therapist to be based in the Ste. Genevieve R-II School District.

The Youth Day Treatment Therapist is responsible for providing evaluation and treatment of children and families. They will facilitate therapeutic activities based on the child’s treatment plan and be a member of the child’s Treatment Team.

Qualifications:
- Master’s degree in social work, counseling, psychology or related human services field.
- Provisional License is required at time of hire (PLPC, LMSW); at least 2 years’ experience in children/family mental health services.
- Must have reliable transportation and the ability to possess a Class E license.

If interested, see further information about the position and fill out an application here: http://www.cccntr.com/JobOpenings/

Beginning in October, the students create a guest list and figure out the amount of ingredients needed for their meal. They then go on a scavenger hunt throughout the grocery store to purchase the items they need. The week of the feast, the students and their teachers and paraprofessionals prepare and cook the meal.

“Our students love this event every year, because they get to spend all day together with their friends from around the school district, cooking and creating this festive atmosphere,” Ms. Kleghorn says. “This year, Mr. Joe Cox’s elementary class joined us in preparing for the event, and we appreciate all of their help in making this event a success!”

#SGFamily #HappyThanksgiving

Ozora Fire Department firefighters Alan Schilli and Sarah Carlson visited Mrs. Rose Kreitler’s preschool classroom to teach students about fire prevention!

Mrs. Carlson, who is a Ste. Genevieve Elementary library aide, read the students a story about fire prevention, and they practiced what to do if their house is on fire, including crawling low to the ground and checking doors before opening them. They learned how to escape out a window and discussed having a safe gathering place outside to meet.

Alan dressed in turnout gear, while Mrs. Carlson explained the importance of each item he put on. Students had the opportunity to hug or shake Alan’s hand to demonstrate firefighters are friendly even when in their gear. The students were also able to check out the fire truck in the parking lot afterward!

We would like to spotlight seventh grader Bennett Walls, who has donated his time over the past several weeks to helping raise funds for a faculty member in need.

“I’m in Student Council, and in that group we try to make a difference,” Bennett says. “So I just wanted to do the same here, make a difference.”

Bennett came up with his own creative plan, organized the logistics through the middle school office and spent his Advisory time each week raising funds. Bennett decided to create his own type of carnival game, where his fellow students could pay to spin a wheel to see how many pieces of candy they could choose.
